titleStmt.title: Resistin is produced by rat pancreatic islets and regulates insulin and glucagon in vitro secretion

analytic.title: Resistin is produced by rat pancreatic islets and regulates insulin and glucagon in vitro secretion

biblStruct.note: Received 18 May 2016 Revised 16 August 2016 Accepted 15 October 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Resistin participates in the regulation of energy homeostasis, insulin resistance, and inflammation.
The potential expression in pancreas, and modulation of the endocrine pancreas secretion by resistin is not well characterized, therefore, we examined it on several levels.

We examined the localization of resistin in rat pancreatic islets by immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence, and the potential presence of resistin mRNA by RT-PCR and protein by Western Blot in these structures.
In addition, we studied the regulation of insulin and glucagon secretion by resistin in pancreatic INS-1E band InR-G9 a-cell lines as well as isolated rat pancreatic islets.
We identified resistin immunoreactivity in the periphery of rat pancreatic islets and confirmed the expression of resistin at mRNA and protein level.
Obtained data indicated that resistin is co-localized with glucagon in pancreatic a-cells.

In addition, we found that in vitro resistin decreased insulin secretion from INS-1E cells and pancreatic islets at normal (6 mM) and high (24 mM) glucose concentrations, and also decreased glucagon secretion from G9 cells and pancreatic islets at 1 mM, whereas a stimulation of glucagon secretion was observed at 6 mM glucose.
Our results suggest that resistin can modulate the secretion of insulin and glucagon from clonal b or a cells, and from pancreatic islets.
White adipose tissue fulfills important endocrine role in controlling the whole body metabolism. 1 Resistin is supposed to represent a novel link between obesity and development of type 2 diabetes. 2
Further investigations changed that view, however, revealed numerous species specific properties and physiological differences of resistin's actions. 3
In obese rodents resistin serum levels are higher than in wild type controls, as a consequence of increased body weight and fat depots. 4
In agreement with this observation, high expression of resistin was found in white adipocytes. 5
esistin increases blood glucose level and impairs glucose transport to the target cells. 6
Moreover, exogenous resistin contributes to insulin resistance in healthy mice (hence named resistin). 2
This effect is reversible upon administration of anti-resistin antibody. 2
All these observations are crucial for the world wide interest of resistin's role in the body. 7
he functions of resistin appear to be speciesspecific.
Discrepancies were reported in humans and rodents. 3,8
First, the main sources of resistin in humans seems to be cells involved in inflammatory responses, especially macrophages. 9
Second, the role of resistin at enhancing insulin resistance in humans is questionable and doubtful. 10

Undoubtedly, resistin seems to contribute to insulin resistance in rodents. 2 However there is still little known about the possible localization of resistin in rat pancreas and regulation of rat pancreatic endocrine functions.

Therefore, the aim of this study was to investigate the conceivable presence of resistin in pancreatic islets, and determine whether resistin may influence insulin and glucagon secretion from clonal a and b cell lines and from pancreatic islets.

div.head: Immunoreactive localization of resistin in rat pancreatic islets

p.s: Resistin immunohistchemical and immunofluorescence staining was observed only in the periphery of pancreatic islets in male Wistar rats (Fig. 1).

In the case of immunohistchemical localization, control incubation of tissue slices with anti-resistin primary antibody and blocking peptide -resistin protein (Biovendor, Czech Republic) was performed.
Observed signal was abolished.
Immunofluorescence technique was used to identified resistin co-expression in glucagon-producing a-cells.
Signals from glucagon and resistin were localized in the same cells.
To prove the lack of glucagon binding by the anti-resistin antibody we performed additional western blots.
One microgram of resistin and glucagon proteins were loaded on 2 gels.
Then samples were transferred into 2 membranes.
The first one was incubated in anti-resistin antibody and the second one was incubated in antiglucagon antibody.
Clear signals were obtained only from resistin lane with anti-resistin antibody and only from glucagon lane with anti-glucagon antibody.
This experiment excluded the possibility of potential crossreactivity of anti-resistin antibody in Western blot as well as in Immunofluorescence.
In above mentioned experiment the same resistin (from Biovendor) was used, glucagon was from Sigma Aldrich cat.
no.
Primary antibodies which were used in additional Western blots were identical with the ones used in main Western blot and Immunofluorescence.
The presence of 2 or even 3 bands is due to a strong tendency of resistin to create dimmers, trimers and hexamers.

div.head: Detection of resistin expression by real time PCR and Western Blotting

p.s: Detection of resistin mRNA in rat pancreatic islets was carried out by real time PCR technique.
As a negative control INS-1E cells producing insulin were used.
These cells are clones of b cells which are located in the center of pancreatic islets.
As a positive control isolated rat adipocytes were used, which are one of the main resistin sources in rat organism.
We found resistin gene expression in pancreatic islets.
The observed expression was lower than in adipocytes but clearly detectable, in contrast to the INS-1E cells (Fig. 2).
Resistin protein expression was quantified by Western blotting technique.
The same positive (adipocytes) and negative (INS-1E cells) controls as in PCR were used.
Results obtained at the protein level corresponded to the results at mRNA level.
Similarly to PCR we observed the highest quantity of resistin in adipocytes, mediate in islets and it was not detectable in INS-1E cells (Fig. 2).

div.head: Insulin secretion from cell lines and pancreatic islets

p.s: All results are presented as a percent of control.
This enables the comparison of the various repeats of experiments.
At 6 mM glucose, resistin inhibited insulin secretion from INS-1E cells by approximately 35% at 1 nM resistin and 50% at 10 nM and 100 nM resistin.

The inhibition of insulin secretion by resistin was (C) Western blotting for resistin and glucagon by using anti-resistin and anti-glucagon antibodies to exclude the cross reactivity between these antibodies.
more potent at 24 mM glucose.
After 90 min of incubation with resistin, insulin secretion decreased by approximately 50% at 1 nM resistin, 70% at 10 nM resistin, and 80% at 100 nM resistin (Fig. 3 A-B).
Analogous secretion experiments were performed using isolated pancreatic islets.
Resistin again decreased insulin secretion in both glucose concentrations in the incubation medium but this effect was lower.

Nevertheless, we found a significant decrease of insulin secretion at 6 mM glucose level (approximately 20% at 100 nM resistin concentration) and similar decrease of insulin secretion at 24 mM glucose level (approximately 10% at 10 nM and 100 nM resistin) (Fig. 3 C-D).

div.head: Glucagon secretion from cell lines and pancreatic islets

p.s: As above mentioned all results are presented as a percent of control.
Variable effects on glucagon secretion were observed in InR-G9 cells exposed to resistin.
At 1 mM glucose, glucagon secretion declined by 20% at 10 nM resistin and 100 nM resistin.
At 6 mM glucose glucagon secretion increased in response to resistin by 40% at 1 nM resistin and near 50% at both 10 nM or 100 nM resistin (Fig. 4 A-B).

In the case of secretion from pancreatic islets at 1 mM glucose glucagon level was also significantly decreased in response to resistin treatment by approximately 15% at 10 nM resistin, and a distinct significant increase at 6 mM glucose (approximately 45%) was found -in the presence of 1 nM and 10 nM resistin and 20% at 100 nM (Fig. 4 C-D).
Our study shows that resistin is expressed in rat pancreatic a-cells, and can modulate secretion activity of clonal cell lines and pancreatic islets.
A novel finding is the detection of resistin protein in rat pancreas by different methods: immunohistochemistry, immunofluorescence, real time PCR and Western blotting.
To our knowledge, studies evaluating resistin immunoreactivity in rat pancreatic islets haven't been published so far.
The presence of resistin-immunoreactivity in pancreatic cells was shown in humans only.
Minn et al. detected positive signals in the center of islets. 11
t suggested that human resistin could be co-expressed with insulin in pancreatic b cells or expressed in a new type of cells.
While, Al-Salam showed that resistin is co-localizated with insulin in human islets 12 .
We assume that pancreatic resistin may lead to paracrine and autocrine regulations within the islets.
So far there has been small number of publications showing the presence of resistin in rat tissues. 5
Surprisingly, in our research we found resistin signals in the periphery of rat pancreatic islets only.
Furthermore, we confirmed that resistin is co-expressed in glucagon-immuoreactive a cells.
To exclude a potential resistin penetration from the blood into the a cells we performed real time PCR analysis.
It confirmed resistin gene expression inside the islets.
Protein localization inside the islets was confirmed also by Western blotting.

It is likely that this opposite localization of resistin in rat and human suggests different local interactions (paracrine and autocrine) between pancreatic hormones within the islets of rat and human.
Therefore, as far as studies of resistin are concerned rat model should not be referred to human one.

Additionally, we found inhibitory influence on insulin secretion from INS-1E cells at physiological as well as supraphysiological glucose concentrations (6 and 24 mM respectively), and similar but less strong effect on pancreatic islets.
Furthermore, resistin also inhibited glucagon secretion from InR1-G9 cells as well as isolated islets at 1 mM glucose and reversely increases glucagon secretion from cells and islets at 6 mM glucose.
Our results were obtained without any stimulants.

Probably the effect of arginine on glucagon secretion might change the results observed in our manuscript (perhaps resistin suppression of glucagon secretion would be more visible or inversely -abolished) but we decided to perform our experiments on basal level without stimulants.
Our main goal was to show the basic influence of resistin on cells and islets even though that influence would be mild.
Results obtained in both, pancreatic b and a cell lines show that resistin can contribute to disturbances in glycaemia.
In experiments at identical glucose and resistin levels on freshly isolated pancreatic islets, resistin was not so effective in regulating glucagon or insulin secretion.
It is possible that compensatory mechanisms prevent from high fluctuations of the secretion of both pancreatic hormones.
Nonetheless, we speculated that reduction of insulin secretion and simultaneous increase of glucagon secretion at normoglycaemia may lead to increased blood glucose level.
We may speculate that mechanisms involved in this effect are connected to increase of SOCS-3 expression and a decrease of Akt phosphorylation inside islets as described Nakata. 13
he influence of resistin on the secretion of insulin and glucagon from pancreatic islets is not well understood.
Nakata et al. revealed no differences in insulin secretion from murine pancreatic islets treated with 10 nM resistin at 2.8 or 8.3 mM glucose for 60 min, as compared to vehicle. 13
However, when the incubation was prolonged until 24 h, a rise of insulin secretion at 2.8 mM glucose was reported.
On the other hand, at 8.3 mM glucose, a decline of insulin secretion was observed.
The increase of insulin secretion at 2.8 mM glucose tempted the authors to conclude that resistin induces a local insulin resistance in pancreatic islets by impairing the autocrine action of insulin.
This hypothesis was supported by the reported increase of SOCS-3 expression and a decrease of Akt phosphorylation in islets.

Our results confirm that resistin can inhibit insulin secretion at physiologically moderate glucose levels (6 to 8.3 mM), which is in agreement with the report by Nakata et al. 13 It seems that resistin can decrease insulin secretion; however this appears to be rather a longer lasting process.

In a different study on pancreatic b cells Brown et al. reported in bTC-6 cell a 70% decrease of insulin receptor mRNA and a 60% decrease of insulin receptor protein after overnight incubation with resistin. 14
his observation may confirm that resistin contributes to insulin resistance in islets.
In BRIN-BD11 b cell line resistin failed to affect insulin secretion at supraphysiologically high glucose (22 mM).
The authors concluded that this observation can be explained by a lower sensitivity of this cell line in comparison to freshly isolated pancreatic islets.
Summarizing, we showed for the first time the presence of resistin in glucagon-immunoreactive cells of the rat pancreatic islets.

Furthermore, we observed that resistin can decrease insulin secretion from b cell lines and pancreatic islets, and increase or decrease glucagon secretion from a cell lines and isolated islets depending on glucose concentration.
All experiments were performed according to the rules issued by the Local Ethical Commission for Investigation on Animals.
Male Wistar rats (8 weeks of age) with an initial body weight 180 § 20g were used.
Animals were maintained at 22 C with 12 h light/dark cycle and had free access to water and standard diet.
At the end of experiments rats were killed by decapitation.
Pancreata for islets isolation and for immunohistochemical studies were collected.
Cells INS-1E were a kind gift from professor Pierre Maechler (University of Geneva Medical Center, Geneva, Switzerland).
INR1-G9 cells 15 were kindly donated by professors W. Knepel and Elke Oetjen (Department of Pharmacology University of G€ ottingen, Germany).
Unless otherwise stated all reagents were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Germany.
Antibodies for immunofluorescence: rabbit anti-rat resistin antibody and rat resistin protein which was used as a blocking peptide and in control Western Blot cat.
no.
RD 381016100 and RD 372016300 respectively were purchased from BioVendor Laboratorni Medicina (Modrice, Czech Republic).
Guinea pig anti-glucagon antibody was bought from Merck Millipore cat.
no.
4031-01F (Darmstad, Germany).
Secondary antibodies: anti-rabbit Cy3 conjugate cat.
no.
A10520 and anti-guinea pig, Alexa Fluor 488 conjugate were used cat.
no.
A11073, Thermo Fisher Scientific (Waltham, USA).
Antibodies for Western Blot: anti-resistin as above and mouse anti-B-actin cat.
no.
A1978, Sigma Aldrich (Saint Louise, USA).
Secondary antibodies anti-rabbit cat.
no.
OAPB01378, Aviva System Biology (San Diego, USA) and anti-mouse cat.
no.
A2304, Sigma Aldrich (Saint Louise, USA).
Additionally glucagon peptide for control Western Blot cat.
no.
G2044 Sigma Aldrich (Saint Louise, USA) was used.
Citrate buffer/Tween-20, pH 6 contained 10 mM disodium citrate, 0.05% Tween-20.
PBS-T buffer of pH 7.3 contained 0.137 M NaCl, 26.86 mM KCl, 9.86 M Na 2 HPO 4 , 2 mM KH 2 PO 4 , 0.1% Tween-20.
Blocking buffer of pH 7.3 contained: 1% BSA, 0.1% Triton X-100, 0.05% Tween-20, 0.05% sodium azide.

Standard incubation medium for INS-1E and InR1-G9 cell lines consisted of RPMI 1640, 10% FBS, and antibiotics (5000 U/100 mL penicillin; 6 mg/100 mL gentamycin; 5 mg/100 mL streptomycin; 125 mg/ 100 mL amphotericin B).
In case of INS-1E cells medium was additionally supplemented with 1 mM Na pyruvate and 50 mM B-mercaptoethanol.
Hanks balanced salt solution (HBSS) of pH 7.4 contained 0.137 M NaCl, 5.37 mM KCl, 4.17 mM NaHCO 3 , 1.26 mM CaCl 2 , 0.84 mM MgSO 4 , 0.44 mM KH 2 HPO 4 , 0.34 mM Na 2 HPO 4 .
Krebs-Ringer buffer (KRB) of pH 7.4 contained 115 mM NaCl, 24 mM NaHCO 3 , 5 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl 2 , 1 mM CaCl 2 , 0.5% BSA.
RIPA buffer contained 50 mM Tris base, pH 8, 150 mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 0,5% Na deoxycholate and 0,1% SDS.

div.head: Tissue sections preparation and immunohistochemical and immunofluorescence analyses

p.s: Rats were decapitated, the pancreas was dissected out and placed in Bouin's reagent, immediately.
Subsequently, fixed pancreases were embedded in paraffin, and sliced in 5 mm sections.

Just before analyses paraffin was removed by heating (60 C, 30 min) and xylene incubation by 30 min and then tissue sections were hydrated using alcohol washes of decreasing concentrations (100%, 85%, 70%, 60%, 50%, water).
Then slices were boiled in citrate buffer in 100 C by 15 min and after cooling were washed in PBS-T.
The immunohistochemical signal was detected using LSAB@+ System HPR kit (DakoCytomation, Denmark).
To minimize the background signal, endogenous peroxidase enzymes were blocked by 3% H 2 O 2 for 7 min After PBS washing unspecific binding sites were blocked by blocking buffer.

Then samples were incubated overnight at 4 C with the primary anti-resistin antibody diluted 1:400 in PBS-T and control slices were incubated with a mix of anti-resistin antibody and 10 mg of blocking peptide (resistin).
Antibody and resistin were previously preincubated at RT for 2 hour.
Samples were thoroughly washed and incubated by 30 min at RT with the secondary (biotinylated) antibody and then were treated for 30 min with streptavidin, conjugated to horseradish peroxidase.
After additional rinse in PBS, slices were covered by DAB reagent for 1 min Haematoxilin staining was then performed for 40 sec to detect nuclei.
Then samples were rinsed with water and dehydrated and mounted on cover glasses were using Roti Histokitt (Carl Roth, Germany).
Images were taken by Carl Zeiss LSM 510 Meta microscope and processed by AxioVision software (rel.
The immunofluorescence signal was detected using anti-glucagon (Merck Millipore, Germany) and antiresistin primary antibody (Biovendor, Czech Republic).
Secondary antibodies anti-guinea pig Alexa Fluor Cy3 and anti-rabbit (Life Technologies, USA) were used.
To minimize the autofluorescence signal sections were blocked by 15 mM glycine for 5 min.
After PBS washing unspecific binding sites were blocked by 0.2% gelatin.
Then samples were incubated 45 min at RT with the primary anti-resistin and antiglucagon antibody diluted 1:400 in 0.2% gelatin-PBS.
As above control slices were incubated with a mix of anti-resistin antibody and 10 mg of blocking peptide (resistin).
Antibody and resistin were previously preincubated at RT for 2 hour.
Samples were thoroughly washed in PBS and incubated by 45 min at RT with the secondary antibody diluted also 1:400.
After additional rinse in PBS, slices were covered by DAPI reagent for 4 min to detect nuclei.
Then samples were mounted on cover glasses were using Roti Histokitt (Carl Roth, Germany).
Images were taken by Carl Zeiss LSM 510 Meta microscope and processed by AxioVision software (rel.
For a single secretion experiment pancreata from 3 rats were combined.
After decapitation, pancreata were filled with 20 mL of ice-cold HBSS and excised.
Distended pancreata were cut in small pieces and digested by 6 -9 mg/3 pancreata collagenase (type P) (Roche Diagnostic, Germany) in HBSS for 11 min at 37 C in a shaking water bath.
The reaction was stopped by adding ice-cold HBSS supplemented with 10% FBS.
Islets were washed and preincubated for 90 min in KRB containing 6 mM glucose.
Secretion was determined by incubating 5 islets for 90 min with resistin (1, 10, 100 nM) in 1 mL KRB at 37 C in 24well plates in 6 duplicates.
The incubations were repeated 3-4 times.
The amount of released insulin or glucagon was determined by RIA kit (Merck Millipore, USA).
The above procedure islets isolation was also used to obtain RNA material for real time PCR.

div.head: Secretion experiments and insulin and glucagon measurement

p.s: Cells were grown until 90% confluency in the RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% (v/v) FBS and antibiotics.
In the case of INS-1E cells medium was additionally supplemented with 1 mM Na pyruvate and 50 mM B-mercaptoethanol.
Unless otherwise stated, all secretion experiments were performed in KRB in 12-well plates.

Cells and pancreatic islets were incubated with resistin at 1, 10, or 100 nM concentration in 6 or 24 mM glucose (INS-1E cells and pancreatic islets) or at 1 or 6 mM glucose (InR1-G9 cells and pancreatic islets).
As glucose is one of the major factors regulating insulin and glucagon secretion we decided to choose glucose concentrations which may simulate some physiological and extreme states.
Glucose 6 mM was used as a typical physiological concentration which is common in blood.
Glucose 1 mM was used as stressful hypoglycemia and clear signal of stimulation of glucagon secretion at minimal insulin secretion.
Glucose 24 mM was used as hyperglycemia model were glucagon secretion is inhibited and strong secretion of insulin is provoked.
Twenty-four hours before the experiments medium was changed to serum free.
After 90 min of incubation medium was collected to determine the concentration of released insulin or glucagon, respectively.
Insulin and glucagon concentrations in incubation media were measured by RIA kit (Merck Millipore, USA).

div.head: Detection of resistin expression by real time PCR

p.s: RNA isolation and reverse transcription was performed as describe previously. 16
In brief, RNA from INS-1E cells, isolated adipocytes and pancreatic islets was isolated by using Tripure Reagent (Roche Diagnostic, Germany), according to attached manual.
Reverse transcription was performed by High Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit (Applied Biosystems, USA).
PCR reaction was made by using Fast SYBR Green Master Mix on QuantStudio 12K Flex thermomixer (Applied Biosystems, USA).
Expression analysis was performed in relation to GAPDH reference gene.
Primers were designed in Primer 3 software and mRNA sequence of rat resistin has been used to designed them (NCBI accession number NM 144741.1).
Primer resistin sequence: forward 5 0 cattgctggtcagtctcc 3 0 ; reverse 5 0 gccgctgtccagtctat 3 0 , product 155 bp.
Primer GAPDH sequence: forward 5 0 ctgcaccaccaactgcttag 3 0 ; reverse 5 0 tgatggcatggactgtgg 3 0 , product 92 bp.

div.head: Detection of resistin expression by Western blotting

p.s: Samples of adipocytes, islets and INS-1E cells were homogenized by sonication in RIPA buffer enriched by protease inhibitors cocktail (Roche Diagnostic, Germany) and centrifuged by 10 min at 12000 g.
Protein content was measured in obtained supernatant using BCA Kit (Thermo Scientific, USA) and 20 mg of total protein was used per lane.
Samples were reduced by B-mercaptoethanol in the ratio 5:1 and heated by 5 min in 95 C. Then protein SDS-PAGE were performed at 140 V.
The next step was semi dry transfer onto nitrocellulose membrane 0.2 mm by 7 min at 0.2 mA using Thermo Scientific Pierce G2 Fast Blotter (Thermo Scientific, USA).
After Ponceau S visualization membrane was blocked in 3% solution of BSA by 60 min and subsequently incubated with primary antibody anti-resistin 1:1000, overnight.

Next day membrane was incubated in secondary anti-rabbit antibody 1:5000 (Aviva System Biology, USA) conjugated with horseradish peroxidase by 60 min and visualization of chemiluminescent signals on VersaDoc detector (Biorad, USA) was carried out.
Similar procedure was applied for B-actin detection.
Primary anti-B-actin antibody (Sigma Aldrich, USA) was used overnight and then membrane was incubated in secondary antibody antimouse (Sigma Aldrich, USA) by 60 min.
For statistical analysis Student's t-test and were performed.
Statistical analyses were performed for a set to 0.05, 0.01 and 0.001 marked by Ã , ÃÃ and ÃÃÃ respectively.
Figure 1.
A1-A2 Detection of resistin protein in the periphery of rat pancreatic islets.
A3 Control without anti-resistin antibody -2 islets are visible.
A4 Control with anti-resistin antibody and blocking peptide.
B1 Detection of glucagon protein (green) in the periphery of rat pancreatic islets.
B2 Detection of resistin protein (red) in the periphery of rat pancreatic islets.
B3 Both channels together and DAPI staining.
B4 Control with anti-resistin antibody and blocking peptide.

Figure 2. (A) Resistin expression measured by real time PCR (2 experiments, n D 3 in each, total n D 6) and (B) Western blotting (3 experiments, n D 1 in each, total n D 3) isolated rat adipocytes (positive control), INS-1E cells (negative control) and rat pancreatic islets.
(C) Western blotting for resistin and glucagon by using anti-resistin and anti-glucagon antibodies to exclude the cross reactivity between these antibodies.
Figure 3. Insulin secretion from INS-1E cell line exposed to resistin at A 6 mM and B 24 mM glucose.
Data are presented as means § SEM; (3 experiments, n D 4 in each, total n D 12).
Insulin secretion from pancreatic islets exposed to resistin at C 6 mM and D 24 mM glucose.
Data are presented as means § SEM; (4 experiments, n D 6 in each, total n D 24).
Figure 4. Glucagon secretion from InR1-G9 cell line exposed to resistin at A 1 mM and B 6 mM glucose.
Data are presented as means § SEM; (3 experiments, n D 4 in each, total n D 12).
Glucagon secretion from pancreatic islets treated with resistin at C 1 mM and D 6 mM glucose.
Data are presented as means § SEM; (3 experiments, n D 6 in each, total n D 18).

analytic.title: Adipokines: inflammation and the pleiotropic role of white adipose tissue
The hormone resistin links obesity to diabetes
Resistin: yet another adipokine tells us that men are not mice
Resistin is expressed in different rat tissues and is regulated in a tissue-and gender-specific manner
Mouse and human resistins impair glucose transport in primary mouse cardiomyocytes and oligomerization is required for this biological action
Resistin -from gene expression to development of diabetes
Role of resistin in insulin sensitivity in rodents and humans
Resistin messenger-RNA expression is increased by proinflammatory cytokines in vitro
Resistin gene expression in human adipocytes is not related to insulin resistance
Resistin is expressed in pancreatic islets
Diabetes mellitus is associated with an increased expression of resistin in human pancreatic islet cells
Resistin induces insulin resistance in pancreatic islets to impair glucoseinduced insulin release
Resistin down-regulates insulin receptor expression, and modulates cell viability in rodent pancreatic beta-cells
Characterization of secretory responses of a glucagon-producing In-R1-G9 cell line
Obestatin inhibits lipogenesis and glucose uptake in isolated primary rat adipocytes
